messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, Probably Ono, early Edo period.  Kanayama is in the right ballpark.  I don t think that it s Myochin, but that is another close to ballpark call.  Not
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
Probably Ono, early Edo period. Kanayama is in the right ballpark. I don't think that it's Myochin, but that is another close to ballpark call. Not Jingo or Akao.

Jim

messages.messageBody:
Anyone have any idea on school, period, etc of this
tsuba? It has been suggested it was Jingo or Kanayama.
Any thoughts appreciated.

http://www.nihontophile.com/Pic%20030.jpg

http://www.nihontophile.com/Pic%20031.jpg

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Andres, It appears to be authentic and of about that period or a little later.  It looks more like Shoami work than Nara, maybe Aizu Shoami.  Nara work
messages.messageBody:
Andres,
It appears to be authentic and of about that period or a little later. It looks more like Shoami work than Nara, maybe Aizu Shoami. Nara work influenced a number of other groups. The part of the composition with the mountain and pagoda is a Kaneie influence as well.

Jim




Dear All,

Can someone give me their opinion on the tsuba depicted in these pics?

http://www.angelfire.com/darkside/necromage/images/konaramaru1.jpg
http://www.angelfire.com/darkside/necromage/images/konaramaru2.jpg

The description is "Early edo period (circa 1650) tetsu (iron) tsuba for
katana, maru gata, (round shaped), ko-nara school, ("old" Nara)".

Do the pics match the description, especially as regards period and
school? Look authentic?

In advance, thanks. Sorry if this is a duplicate. I sent a similar one
this morning but never saw it come through.

Best Regards,

Andres Pedraza
